reviews.title: Excellent Day Trip
text: I recommend you do a free online one hour booking to visit the  center. We  did a lunch time booking of the
Center  and then visited the Aga Khan Museum next door .

reviews.title: A wonder of the world
text: Absolutely wonderful place to visit for everyone, A must visit when in Toronto, we take our friends and family there all the times

reviews.title: Amazing experience
text: The 8th wonder of the world, an exceptionally amazing place to visit it starts with the architectural beauty that captivates your eyes as you enter the grounds and then all your senses come to life as you enter it is truly the most magnificent place that i have seen.
The restaurant is also an amazing place to eat, everything about this place will leave you happy and fulfilled.
Just do it take the family and visit, tell them uncle Al sent you.

reviews.title: Afternoon well spent!
text: The building is very beautiful and has peaceful ambience and surroundings. It was a worth it visit and was very educational with the tour guide explaining in detail the history of Islam and especially the Ismailis (followers of the hereditary Imam, decedent from Prophet Mohammad, PBUH, His Highness Prince Karim Aga Khan), The inner court and prayer house is very serene and has a beautiful vista of Toronto from the roof top.
While there, visited the Aga Khan Museum, another worth it visit. Smooth check in at front reception desk and the area well planned with very friendly staff.
The permanent exhibition downstairs is amazing and gives you an insight into Medieval history of Islam. Very well preserved artifacts to show the glory of that time period.

I was lucky to see Caravans of Gold, Fragments in Time exhibition, which opened my eyes to the fact, that Africa was not the DARK Continent the Europeans had been calling it during the medieval times and later.

reviews.title: GORGEOUS!
text: So, when I first visited, I thought it was a mosque like no other, unfortunately however, worship is only allowed for Ismaili Muslims. But the centre does offer free tours, and you can visit the centre for various events that take place throughout the year. A beautiful compromise between Islamic and western architecture, the whole area has this divine and spiritual aura that can't be explained, and I highly recommend visiting. But I also suggest one visit the neighbouring Aga Khan museum in addition to the Ismaili centre, as the former has dining options, as well as requires more time to explore.

reviews.title: Turned away
text: If you are looking for a place of prayer and contemplation the Ismaili Centre is not it.  Best viewed from the outside only.

reviews.title: Educational Visit
text: Whilst visiting the Aga  Khan Museum, we paid a visit to this centre for a tour (which was free) of this fantastic building.
We were shown round by a superb lady guide whose knowledge, experience and personality was most welcome.
The facilities are superb with the prayer room and events rooms
a great asset to the complex.

reviews.title: Blue Dot Ensemble
text: This was a delightful musical expedition from the 13th century to the 17th century highlighting music dance and poetry from the near east to the West.
A lot of this music was inspired by the poetry of the world renowned Sufi mystic poets Rumi and Hafiz.
This tear jerking experience was crowned by a delightful serving of Chai tea and freshly prepared somosas.
Whilst the $25 seemed steep at the outset it turned out to be well worth it.
The event organizers led by Salima and Nureen did a
Great job.

reviews.title: The Ismaili community is justifiably proud...
text: We had no idea that there was such a magnificent Ismaili Centre in Toronto, and that there were free, guided tours of this community hub. We only learned of this hidden gem from the folks at the Aga Khan Museum when we visited - and were urged to go across the garden to catch the 11 a.m. guided tour.
We are so glad we did!

We were warmly greeted at the door by volunteer guides (all the guides are members of the Ismaili community and provide tours as a means of providing service). We were provided with an excellent tour of the centre by Mr. Allyabdul, a former teacher, who was knowledgeable and very clear in his presentation of the history of the centre, its architecture, art and the ethos of the Ismaili Muslim community. His pride was evident as he took us about - a pride that was absolutely warranted.
The tour was freely given, and was terrific. I now know where friends and colleagues who are members of Toronto's Ismaili community worship.
This tour was a wonderful gift!

reviews.title: This is a must see
text: There are free guided tours all day.  It is a simply remarkable place to visit topped off by the prayer centre which gives an aura of spirituality even for those who are not religious.  There is a feeling of peace and tranquility which I have not experienced in Toronto before.

reviews.title: The Jewel of TORONTO
text: Mastermind architecture.
The ISMAILI centres are symbolic markers of the permanent presence and core value of ISMAILI communities around the world.
When you visit the centre you will attention to details and concept behind this Amazing building.

reviews.title: Hidden treasure of Toronto
text: This was my second time at the Centre. My friends from Florida wanted to see Aga Khan Museum , so we took tour of the Museum. After the tour , they inquired what was that White building with glass Dom.
We ended taking the one hour tour of the Ismaili Centre. My friends did not walk away enjoying the architecture tour but walked away with some background and knowledge about Ismailis and Aga Khan.
If one ends up at the Centre, tour of the Museum is a must and vice versa.

reviews.title: Peaceful and beautiful
text: Take a free tour! We were lucky enough to have our tour guided by our friend's father. Don't miss the opportunity to visit the Centre and the Aga Khan Museum. Looking forward to going back in the summer to walk the grounds as well.

reviews.title: Beautiful architecture
text: Beautiful architecture, super cool place, it was clean. It was also breath taking, there was nothing like this i have ever seen before. Would recommend visiting!!

reviews.title: Great concert in a great building
text: We went here for the Against the Grain production of Osvaldo Golijov's "Ayre." The way the conecrt was presented took us to several rooms, including the theatre. The architecture is impressive. The music was impressive, too.

reviews.title: Awesome, must seen
text: Beautiful and amazing building and clean. Must see. Book tour and go visit with your family and friends. You will appreciate the architect and way building is positioned.

reviews.title: Love it Everytime
text: Took a tour last night starting at 8:30pm. Serene and calm place. Learn more each time I take it. Would recommend it to those who have spiritual inclinations.

reviews.title: Serene cultural showcase
text: If you drive on the Don Valley Parkway, you've probably noticed an oddly shaped but beautiful glass "dome" not far from the highway on the east side. The IC is adjacent to the better-known Aga Khan Museum and shares some beautifully landscaped grounds with it but is a separate entity. The IC seems to be a combination of prayer hall and a sort of community centre with an eye to mindfully interfacing with the general public (outside the hours of worship). Our small group took a guided tour and were bowled over by the building's hybrid of modern aesthetics and an eclectic approach to Ismaili Muslim tradition. Our tour guide was well-informed and gracious, and we emerged with a feeling of serenity and appreciation for Ismaili culture. To us this was an even better experience than touring the Aga Khan Museum next door. After our tour, we dined at Diwan, within the Museum, and had a delicious though somewhat pricey meal -- which we didn't mind at all because the IC tour was free of charge.
